title: Before 1 July 2018, will Ashraf Ghani cease to be president of Afghanistan?
preds: He saves his face with it
No he stays because he wants to save his face.

WoC @ 1%. Boring. Makes me want to go high just in case there is an assassination.  So if Ghani takes flight we have to wait until July 21st? Hmm interesting, death is much more likely then!
Update for time, prob is now rounded to 0.

Updating for passage of time. Still he is more mayor of Kabul than president of GIROA. This could actually go up depending on how the ongoing taliban offensive proceeds and if POTUS decides it is finally time to cut losses.
Further winding down with time. Initial forecast was 4% in 7 months.  No change in the assumptions that underpinned that forecast.  Now only 1.5 months remaining.

Ghani has stated he intends to rule until May 2019. With less than 2 months until the deadline for this question, Ghani's exit seems improbable. https://ariananews.af/may-2019-will-be-the-end-of-my-presidency-ghani/

I am sympathetic to Colls view that the incipient and growing middle class, the Pakistani diaspora that Pakistan is capable of a democratic and economic level of India and that is the ultimate hope.
As far as  Ghani,he  appears no better off than Najibullah was in 1979 ruling over Kabul and and archipelago of urban citadels and bombings and will persist thru new elections.

The amount of coalition forces at 10 percent of McChystal is enough to keep govt from toppling not enough to effectively govern until Afghan Army gets there.

Ghani's presidency will continue through 2018 at least, because of external support of Ghani through international institutions and his increased popularity over recent negotiations with the Afghan Taliban. Though the Taliban has given a "cool" reception to recent peace talks, Ghani remains popular among the people.
Instability is endemic to Afghanistan but no credible alternative currently exist, for the near future he is the only hope.

No credible challengers that would be supported by the US and other countries with military presence in Afghanistan, and while there are significant stability problems in Afghanistan it appears unlikely that instability will rise to the level that would affect the office of the presidency by 1 July.

With only three months left only a Major public upheveal might end his presidency before Deadline. While there are increasing protests the momentum does not seem sufficient. Another factor is political rivalry, foremost with CEO Abdullah. However this is an older conflict and there is no Special reason why it would lead to a political coup just now. While both factors for themselves seem minor, in combination they might form the Dynamics required to end his presidency or drive him away
Only 3 months to go.  Elections are set for October.  Basically this is my estimate of the chances of an assassination, government collapse, or uprising in this short time frame.

Maintaining forecast: 
IEC have set parliamentary and local district elections for October 20 2018. The chairman Gula Jan Abdul Badi said “voter registration would start in mid-April”
“The main challenges ahead of the vote are registering Afghans, many of whom do not have identification documents, and setting up ballot stations in remote areas. Plans for voter security and preventing fraud are also critical.” 
(https://www.reuters.com/article/us-afghanistan-election/afghanistan-sets-october-date-for-much-delayed-elections-idUSKBN1H61C1)  October 20 date seems ambitious given the security situation, along with a history of voter fraud etc. The result of the parliamentary elections held on September 18, 2010 were still not finalised after the authorities said the results would be known October 30. 
(http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-11312120)
Assuming the elections happen on October 20, the final results will take at least a month if not more to be determined. It seems more likely that any contest to Ghani’s presidency would occur around the results of the election, rather than July 1.

The first step is measuring leadership exit is to evaluate leadership-edit indicators of the home state. Life expectancy at birth for males, according to the World Bank for Afghanistan, is ~62 (2015 data). According to Wikipedia, Ashraf Ghani, is 68 years old and thus has surpassed national life expectancy data. According to online sources, Ghani does not seem to have any public health records showing any diseases or issues (i.e., heart issues). Ashraf Ghani's personal indicators show that as a healthy individual, he will not cease to be president of Afghanistan. However, according to the World's Bank's poverty headcount ratio at national poverty lines (% of population), 35.8% live at the poverty line as of 2015. This is an important indicator on the national level to assess public opinion and health of citizens. In 2017 Trump announced new plans for the "war" in Afghanistan - which he will not stay consistent on as he does not stay focus on one thing, rather tends to focus on domestic politics. In 2014, U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry set up an agreement that placed Ghani in power; thus the US really cannot remove him from the given power. Ghani's removal will have to come from a national movement, citizens protesting Taliban and ISIS controlled areas to the government.  Since Ghani's support does not come from Afghan minorities - July 1 2018 is too soon for a removal of the president by the minorities of the country. According to The Diplomat "The most recent survey conducted on the people of Afghanistan showed that the public’s faith in state institutions stood at a 10-year low, with only 37 percent of those surveyed holding confidence in the Afghan parliament and 35 percent confident in government ministers. The impact of identity politics is most visible in the survey when seen through ethnic lines." I will take longer than July 2018 in order to leadership exit that will cause conflict/war in Afghanistan since it is a weak state but does have a strong society embedded in religion and nationalism. Afghan's will have to choose if removing their leader is worth war in their state.  https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SP.DYN.LE00.MA.IN?locations=AF&view=chart
https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SI.POV.NAHC?locations=AF

I see no reason why President Ghani would flee, especially with a proposed build up US forces in Afghanistan, and the ANA and ANP are still largely directed by ISAF.  Ghani is not trusted by many Afghans but he is a world bank guy and we won't let him fall.

Ghani enjoys support from the United States, EU members, China, Russia, and India.   He has demonstrated competence as president (far more than Karzai did), and has somehow managed to find the right balance to keep Abdullah Abdullah from breaking the delicate power-sharing arrangement they have.  Also, there is no alternative candidate who reaches across ethnic and tribal lines like Ghani is able to do. You can't beat somebody with nobody. My 3% chance of Ghani not being president on October 1 is, sadly, a reflection of the risk of assassination (or natural death) while in office.
battle events (ACLED) show much lower activity this quarter compared to 2017

I think Noor has stepped aside as Gov. of a ethnic northern province to challenge or help a challenger to Ghani's seat and I would not rule out Abduhulla either. Like his predecessor he'll stay in office till a Loya Jerga is held. That will be during or after Poppy Harvest season but before winter.

Ghani is relatively young and healthy, so natural death before July is unlikely. The support of the 25 nations in the Kabul Process gives legitimacy to his government and puts international pressure on the Taliban to be a "part of the government". The powersharing approach opens the doors for Taliban to be part of next year's election...which is an eternity in Afghan years. ISIS actions remain unpredictable.
Further update with time:  4% with 7mth to go, now only 3.5 of those 7 months remaining.  No significant changes warranting revision of the assumptions I made in the initial forecast.

Cannot rule out coup or assassination. But he seems pretty firmly in control for now.
Average life expectancy in 2014 in Afghanistan was ~61 years, Ashraf Ghani is 68. Political machinations too. Support from the US and compromise with main rival.

The probability of Ghani ceasing to be President of Afghanistan by July 1, 2018 is very low in spite of the "tenuous stability" of his government. Domestically and internationally, there is a lack of mounting pressure on Ghani to step down in the immediate future, and Afghanistan's parliamentary election, which could be a factor in Ghani's potential decision to step down, is not due until July 7. Another possibility of him ceasing to be president is through assassination/attack by terrorists, which is also very unlikely, considering his recent statement that he would unconditionally negotiate with the Taliban. Overall, Ghani has a very slim possibility of not remaining in office as president before July 1.
It is in the U.S. best interest for things to be as stable as possible.

,,,Thousands of supporters greeted Dostum as he arrived in his northern stronghold of Sheberghan. During a speech given at a stadium there, he stated that he could “destroy the Taliban and al Qaeda” if supported by the US, saying that “the US needs strong friends like Dostum.” The Obama-era US Ambassador to Afghanistan, Karl Eikenberry, an academically inclined retired United States Army lieutenant general of the political school, warned that Dostum’s presence in the country could “endanger much of the progress made in Afghanistan.” Up until then, the regions controlled by Dostum along with the other minority groups had been resistant to Talib insurgency, yet the State department still pursued the racist policy of supporting candidates from the majority Pashtun ...
The parliamentary elections are not until  7 July 2018, no change of that magnitude is likely before these elections.
A lot of ppl place extremely low probabilities of this but I feel many wildcards exist--assassination attempts. The answer cannot be well below 5%.
Little reason for US to back a replacement.

I think there is a high chance that Ghani will remain president because he has American support and no other group has enough power to force him out of Kabul. Abdullah may gain support of many warlords and members of parliament but he will not be able to mount a serious military or political challenge to take the capital by force or pressure Ghani to resign. Ghani controls the military and is a skillful politician to ensure he has enough support within Kabul.

I think there is about a 15% chance of Ghani to out before 1 July 18. I think that his nearest opponent Abdullah Abdullah was never "OK" with the election results from June 2014, and it took Ghani and Abdulla until September ( and much US prodding)  to get a power sharing deal completed. Abdullah has support with many conservatives in the country and can be seen as someone to get rid of corruption and unite the country. Add to this the widespread perception (in some cases warranted) of both incompetency and corruption in the Afghan election process as a whole and there is an undercurrent of doubt surrounding Ghani. Realistically, I don't see him being forced out, however there is more here than a flat 0% probability.
There exist no causal mechanism for him to leave before 1 July 2018.
68 years old. Always some risk of violence in Afghanistan.

For this week, I chose to take on the question: “Before 1 July 2018, will Ashraf Ghani cease to be president of Afghanistan?”  I am predicting and assigning a valuation of 3% that this event will occur.  The low probability of this event occurring is based upon several factors.  The event has only about 4 months and 1 week to occur.  Ashraf Ghani has been president of Afghanistan since 2014 and does not seem to be interested in stepping down voluntarily or due to a democratic election.  Afghanistan’s Independent Election Commission announced that the country will hold its parliamentary and district council elections on 7 July 2018, which is 6 days after the 1 July 2018 deadline in the question.  Also, this proposed election is scheduled to take place 3 years past the expiration of the sitting parliament’s 5-year mandate.  A reshaping of the parliament and district councils could factor into Ghani’s decision to step down, but in the unlikely event that it even takes place, it will occur after the deadline in the question.  Historically, elections in Afghanistan face major hurdles and difficulties due to declining security and safety in many parts of the country.  The political instability and the public’s insecurity will likely derail the parliamentary election, which undoubtedly will result in Ghani’s power grip on the Afghani presidency.  Ghani is a slow reformer and takes many actions that may be deemed as autocratic in nature, which impede the opposition to form and contest the government’s power.

In order to answer this question, we have to consider the flashpoints that could lead to him ceasing to be president prematurely. Potential flashpoints:  Resurrgences of Taliban and US Troop Deployment - 
The Taliban has resurfaced and have received re-newed focus by the Trump Administration. This has led to an increase in the deployment of US troops, which could counter the threat posed by this group, decrease the number of attacks by it, and thus address security concerns.
Or, this could also incite the Taliban to carry out more attacks on both Afghanis and foreigners. There was a recent attack by the Taliban in January 2018 that killed over 100 people. More attacks like this wouold most likely lead to more anti-government protests calling at the minimum for security reforms, such as in July 2017. This troop deployment would seem to put the focus on the US as compared to the Afghani President. That being said, there is the other possibility that the President could be perceived as in league with the US.  Islamic State - 
The Islamic State has had attacks in Afghanistan as late as 2017. This is another threat to President Ghani's power that he has to address. Ethnic tensions - 
There has been ongoing ethnic tensions in the country. The President has not helped bridge these gaps, instead making preferential appointments to people who are part of his Pashtun ethnic group, and minimalizing the role of the Hazara, Tajik and Uzbek groups. This does not appear to have improved with the attempted and resisted recall of two governors. Potential ways the President could be removed:
Voted out of office - There is no election before July 2018. I was unable to find immediate information in regards to the possibility of a special election.  Killed - He could be killed or assassinated, by a rival ethnic group, the Uprising for Change Protesters, or the Taliban. Whether one considers the possibility of Ghani being removed from office via diplomatic or undiplomatic, peaceful or violent means, there does not seem to be enough incentive at this late stage. A move to outster him by a rival ethnic group would spoil any chance they had at leading a unified Afghanistan. 
Now this may change if he runs for re-election and succeeds or appears about to succeed.
The Taliban is the wild card as it is an ever-present threat and they have less reason to mind the democratic process. As stated previously, they carried out an attack in January, so the probability cannot be 0%. NOTE: All of this is couched on the rational-actor model. It is entirely possible that any actor, whether an individual, ethnic, group, political party or institution could have a different mental-calculus from what we consider rational. Additional resources:
https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2018-02-18/second-afghan-governor-defies-president-ghani
http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-12024253

Based on media reports, it seems like President Ghani may be creating an atmosphere of uniting people against him. 
Last week, Ghani asked Abdulkarim Khaddam, the governor of the northern province of Samangan, to step down. It seems to be heading into the same territory as the Ghani-Noor situation, with Khaddam refusing to go saying: “I have served Samangan well and my people won’t let me go.” 
“The standoff has underlined the fractious political climate, marked by increasingly open divisions between Afghanistan’s mix of different ethnicities.” 
(https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/afghan-provincial-governor-defies-ghanis-order-to-step-down) 
No doubt issues involving ethnicity are being exacerbated by the controversial launch of the e-NIC’s which “will include ethniticy and nationality of the cardholder.” 
After the establishment of the National Unity Government, “Ghani approved the law of population registration in which the inclusion of nationality and ethnicity information was not included.” However this changed in November 2017, when the AF senate approved a legislative decree issued by Ghani stating the e-NICs will contain information on ethnicity and nationality. 
(https://www.tolonews.com/index.php/afghanistan/abdullah-calls-delay-e-nic-issuance)  Security: 
Haroun Mir, an independent analyst and former government security adviser told the WP: “People did not suddenly become afraid, but this violence has added to their frustrations with the government. It showed a total failure of institutions and leadership” (https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/afghans-fearing-more-insurgent-violence-feel-abandoned-by-struggling-government/2018/02/09/29196310-0b50-11e8-998c-96deb18cca19_story.html?utm_term=.b48f8d228950) 
Zahir Qadir, an MP from Nangahar who recently launched an opposition party, whilst speaking at a gathering accused Ghani at of monopolising power. “Participants at the gathering said government has failed to maintain people’s security” (https://www.tolonews.com/index.php/afghanistan/ghani%C2%A0will-lead%C2%A0country-crisis%C2%A0%C2%A0e-nic%C2%A0decision-noor)  Noor: 
“The final round of talks between Jamiat-e-Islami party of AF and the presidential palace (ARG) have hit another deadlock as negotiators from the two sides failed to reach consensus on some key issues that appear to have prolonged the weeks long stalemate” 
Noor said: “We will organise three-day protests on 27, 28 February and 1 March…” (https://www.tolonews.com/index.php/afghanistan/noor-warns-mass-protests-talks-hit-impasse) 
The article includes a list of Jamiat's demands, such as “holding the parliamentary and district council elections on time, and rolling out the e-NIC based on the law already approved”  I find it interesting that there haven’t been any reports of Noor calling for Ghani to step down (at least not that I have found yet), reiterating the view I have taken that Noor’s party seems to be respecting the democratic process. 
Maintaining forecast for now, but will continue to look for any international response to the situation as a marker of the severity - after all, seems very unlikely that progress can be made against the Taliban and IS in an atmosphere of political discord.

While it is possible, and perhaps likely it will happen, it wont happen before 1 July 2018.  I do see a continued rise in the Taliban and unless it is stopped, I do believe the Taliban will once again take over Afghanistan, but not this quickly.
He does not look like Zuma

There is yet to be a situation where a military coups or popular uprising has upended the Afghanistan power system. While Ghani may not be popular, though that is hard to accurately verify, he is duly elected. Ghani may be voted out of office via parliamentary procedure, but not until a new parliament in elected later this year, which will probably not happen before July.

Ashraf Ghani as been a well respected and a favorable president of Afghanistan since his election win. He has the support and backing of the US government, his resume and credentials are second to none. While there are some domestic turbulences and outspoken opponents (Atta Noor), Ghani has taken the presidency in such a calm and collected manner, I find it difficult to believe that the Afghan people will want to throw out that vital attitude and methodology of government. The country has been in a chaotic environment for a very long time, Ghani has brought about some peace and calmness to the long and tiring storm. Because of Atta Noor's consistent rebuttal and rivalry, I do think there will be more domestic drama but I do not think it will be enough to have Ghani out of the country. Afghanistan relies too much on US support and help and the US is unlikely to back a unpredictable candidate like Noor.  https://globalvoices.org/2018/02/05/in-afghanistan-governors-dont-just-step-down-because-you-ask-them-to/
Drawdown of US forces may leave him open to bring overthrown.
Not aware of realistic alternatives in next 4 months.

Maintaining forecast for now, but will wait for more clarification on the date of the elections before adjusting my forecast: 
“Afghanistan’s long-delayed parliamentary and local council elections scheduled for July this year may have to be pushed back for another three months, an election commissioner said, citing organisational challenges”
“We are ready to hold the elections with two or three months delay, but the security agencies must tell us whether they are ready,” Wasima Badghisi, deputy head of operations at the Independent Election Commission told Reuters.” 
(https://www.reuters.com/article/us-afghanistan-election/afghanistan-parliament-elections-likely-delayed-until-october-idUSKBN1FO0BZ?il=0)

No major changes in dynamics since my initial forecast: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/631465.  Perhaps a slight weakening in Ghani's position given the standoff with Noor that started in December ... but given the only realistic alternative to step into the Presidency before the election is Abdullah, and he gave his approval to sacking Noor (and also seems to have lost the support of his party), I am not sure that that makes any significant difference in the chance that Ghani will be forced out before July.  Given that initial forecast was made with 7 months to go, and there is now 5 months to go, a slight change with the winding down of the clock. References:

While it seems that there is growing factionalism in Afghanistan, it doesn’t seem to be aimed at specifically replacing Ghani, but rather at eroding support for the entire federal government. I don’t think that anyone will replace him as president, because people are building their own regional power bases instead of targeting his office.

Higher than the averages I see below, 3.5 years into a 5 year term. July would be just 9 months before next election. Significant domestic protests & a cold shoulder from U.S. could prompt a special election.

Terrorist organizations are still quite active in Afghanistan and add a strong element of unpredictability to the situation - leading me to temper my original forecast. Relative political/institutional stability still favors remaining in office.
Leaders are unlikely to make a run for it without pressure, the situation is bad, but without some new pressure to change his mind, odds are he will stay put.

In fact Ashraf Ghani is not really ruling his country. But it's very likely he will stay president of Afghanistan till July.
I do not believe he will leave the presidency in advance of elections in 2019, however, his standoff with Governor Noor does increase the risk to greater than 0.

The continued support from the West, especially the U.S. government should prove enough for Ghani to maintain a stronghold on the Presidency in the immediate short-term. The decision by America to continue its military presence in the country provides a layer of security for the Ghani government. Additionally, several Western leaders have been applying pressure to members of parliament in the last few months to give Ghani room to continue to implement his desired reforms. His standing in the international community as a western educated reformer provides strong ties to important backers.  Although the items mentioned above provide a sense of security Ghani, there is not at least a chance he will be removed from office either voluntarily or by force during 2018. The sudden resurgence of the Taliban and increasing violence in the country threaten to derail any progress Ghani has made in making the country safer. In addition, his biggest challenger. Noor, continues to hold the Kabul's feet to the fire and could prove to be a major threat to the Ghani government. These two items, aided by the unrest of elected Parliament members if Afghanistan fails to hold a parliamentary election in 20018, could see him being removed from office in 2018. Thus the outside, 5% chance.

due  to overwhelming support from the United States and its allies it is highly unlikely that Ashraf will steep down. He may be overthrown if Noor decides to strengthen alliances with the remains of ISIS , Al Qaeda and the Taliban he ,may succeed in a short overthrow but this would lead to massive destabilization in the region as was seen in the US Afghan and Iraq invasion of 2002-2003. due to this is seems very unlikely that  Noor would decide to take violent action.

“The stand-off between President Ghani and Atta Mohammad Noor, is increasingly turn into a battle over next years presidential election.” 
“Noor, a leader in the Jamiat-i Islami party and governor of the strategic province of Balkh, is defying Ghani, denouncing the “weak, lazy and corrupt” Kabul government in daily rallies with thousands of supporters and warning the government against trying to remove him by force.” 
Noor not only has the support of the Afghans but also the U.S. “Balkh is one of Afghanistan’s most stable and prosperous provinces, with a much smaller Taliban and Islamic State presence than in other northern regions” 
(https://www.reuters.com/article/us-afghanistan-governor-atta-noor/stand-off-over-powerful-afghan-governor-foreshadows-bitter-election-fight-idUSKBN1EW07N) He successfully implemented a poppy eradication program which reduced poppy cultivation from 7200 hectares in 2005 to 0 in 2007. (Why reducing poppy farming is important: https://www.theguardian.com/news/2018/jan/09/how-the-heroin-trade-explains-the-us-uk-failure-in-afghanistan). Though Noor is an outspoken critic of the U.S. strategy in Afghanistan.  The Presidential Palace announced that Sayed Hafizullah Hashemi was appointed as the new election commissioner. 
“Spokesman of the Chief Executives Office, Majib Rahman Rahimi said: “It is the expectation of the Afghan people and the international community that they (election commission) should accelerate their work. The country’s political stability is dependent on this issue.” (https://www.tolonews.com/afghanistan/election-commission%C2%A0asked-%C2%A0accelerate-reforms-process) 
This sentiment was also reiterated in a UN article: “Representatives of civil society networks from northeastern Afghanistan met in Fayzabad to initiate dialogue with local authorities on upcoming elections and to discuss civil society recommendations for the electoral process. 
“Participants stressed that conducting elections as scheduled is a matter of bolstering public trust in the current government and democratic processes in the country.” (https://unama.unmissions.org/civil-society-northeast-dialogue-local-authorities-upcoming-elections)  Given that the process of holding a parliamentary election is underway, it doesn’t seem likely there would be a move to remove Ghani in the next seven months, provided that the election does take place on July 7.

Ghani enjoys widespread international support and recognition as a leader, particularly from the US government. Trade deals with surrounding countries and economic development should improve stability in the country. However, unnatural death due to terrorism is not all that unlikely even if Ghani has popular support and good security.
Seems unlikely given increased US military support, Abdullah's pacification, and the unrest in Balkh surrounding one of Ghani's biggest critics
Players in Pakistan would gain from his demise,  reducing US influence in both
Taliban will not become an existential threat before July

Hekmatyar, the Cersei Lannister of Afghanistan.  And with him Ghani plausibly adds Pakistan to the countries he can deal with in serious bids to to their interests.  That'd be quite a feat considering the US and India are already on that list.

I'm not sure how Ghani would be removed except by death (natural or not). His detractors would need the cooperation of the military to remove him. The military will not bite the hand that feeds it, which is to say that they will not depose a president supported by the United States.
Very difficult to say, given the tenuous internal situation.
Not the safest job in the world, but he has held it for over 3 years so should see out the term (inshallah)

Afghanistan has no stability at all. Its Ashraf Ghani is burn out... but he has a lot of prestige in the international community and there is no clear contender, as long as division prevails so will he.

Afghanistan is relatively stable at this moment. Ultra islamistic forces like The Taliban are also bound in other conflicts. In an unexpected event, like the fall of the mulah regime in Teheran, there could be a chain reaction in the region, motivating Islamistic Forces to attack Kabul. Even so there is a negligible plausibility to destroy the regular army and permanently take over the capital of Afghanistan.
Its only a matter of time
Because places in trouble nowadays, even when it has been for quite some time, are evolving now very quickly.
It is not in the US interests to let that happen.

Open defiance of his order by Atta Mohammed Noor makes it clear how little power he has and if someone does persuade a few important figures in the military, and get America's blessing, a coup would be very easy.
I doubt there will be any change in the government of afghanistan in so short a time.

Maintaining forecast: despite increasing pressure from political groups within the country, Ghani still has strong international support. 
The Jamiat-e Islami party has threatened to withdraw support for President Ghani, after the recent decision, to remove Atta Mohammad Noor as governor of Balkh. The party in a statement said: “If the presidential palace does not reconsider its one-sided action which is misusing the presence of the international community, Jamiat-e Islami will nullify the national unity government agreement and will employ all options to defend the legitimate rights of the people” (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-afghanistan-politics/afghanistan-political-turmoil-deepens-as-regional-leader-ousted-idUSKBN1EE16A)
Presidential elections will occur in 2019. Barring an assassination he will remain in power through this date

The next presidential election does not take place until 2019. Ghani is the second president after Karzai and, in that time, there has not been a presidential transition outside of election. I don't believe popular resistance is enough to remove him from office prior 1 July 2018.

The slowly diminishing likelihood of parliamentary elections next July seems to carry a high risk of taking Ghani down.
A recent NY Times article stated: “Mr Ghani’s critics are losing patience, turning to public demonstrations, issuing ultimatums or threats, and joining in calls for a nationwide, traditional referendum on his authority…Ghani has reacted in ways that seem panicked: ordering corruption investigations against critics, barred government employees from joining demonstrations and been accused of grounding the flight of a powerful northern governor to keep him from joining an opposition meeting.” 
Mohammed Umer Daudzai, a former interior minister, said the broader problem was “the governments shrinking political base” 
An opposition faction group, run by former president Hamid Karzai is calling for an loya jirga to determine Ghanis fate as President. 
“Other groups critical of Mr Ghani have agreed to show restraint as long as he delivers elections and electoral reforms” 
(https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/12/world/asia/afghanistan-ashraf-ghani-elections.html?_r=0)
The problem is also extending into the hands of the U.S. military: “ For American officials: some of their closest Afghan allies over the years, still essential to the military campaign, are rallying against a political leadership in Kabul that is perceived to be protected by the Americans.” Namely, General Abdul Raziq, Kandahar province police chief, was host to the most recent opposition rally. 
A spokesman for U.S. General Nicholson said “the commander encourages Afghan police and military leaders to remain apolitical” (https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/12/world/asia/afghanistan-ashraf-ghani-elections.html?_r=0)  President Ghani’s recent legislative order on control of Afghan airspace by “airplanes and military helicopters of other nations was approved by only one-third of parliament members in attendance” (http://www.tolonews.com/afghanistan/law-use-afghan-air-space-approved) 
Progress was made last week when 12 minister candidates were introduced to parliament, “all but one - the only woman- passed the vote of confidence”. This comes after almost a year of more than half of Afghanistan’s cabinet members being in an acting capacity. (https://www.afghanistan-analysts.org/afghanistan-has-now-a-constitutional-cabinet-eleven-minister-candidates-received-votes-of-confidence/)
President Ghani recently received backlash after a comment on women’s headscarfs. A statement from the Afghan Presidential Palace said: “The President is a very prominent advocate of women’s rights and has taken unique steps to strengthen their position since his tenure as the president of Afghanistan” (http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-42215547) 
However, “Human Rights Watch’s Barr says that gender-equality in Afghanistan lags behind Pakistan and Iran, which took in a combined six million Afghan refugees during the soviet war.” The article also stated, “in rural areas, the number of girls in school is now declining” (https://news.nationalgeographic.com/2017/12/afghan-girl-home-afghanistan/)  According to the Afghanistan Analysts Network: 
“The unresolved issue of the electoral constituencies, along with other problems, such as lack of clarity about the election budget, the still lingering debate to use of technology in the election and the divisions in the IEC discussed in previous reports have already pushed the timeline for any 2018 polls back even more.” (https://www.afghanistan-analysts.org/the-afghanistan-election-conundrum-3-the-dilemma-of-electoral-constituencies/) Maintaining forecast for now but will be trying to figure out how much patience the opposition groups will have in terms of waiting for parliamentary elections, i.e. are they willing to wait an extra 3 months? Or will there be a genuine attempt to force Ghani out before July?

Afghan presidential elections have been roughly adhered to since 2009
Ghani has a strong background in World bank etc which would make him more likely to respect electoral results
He should stand again
He won reasonably comfortably incumbents should have an advantage

The relatively new U.S.-Afghan campaign of targeting opium refinement facilities comes with the potential backlash against the Afghan government:  While President Ghani announced strong support for the campaign, “Some legislators and provincial representatives expressed worries that civilians could be harmed. Others dismissed the campaign as a dramatic but misplaced effort to showcase Washington’s determination to go after insurgent bastions and criminal activities as part of its new military strategy.” (https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/afghan-leaders-in-helmand-criticize-us-airstrikes-on-taliban-drug-labs/2017/11/21/7130d556-cec5-11e7-a87b-47f14b73162a_story.html?utm_term=.9c6ef5d579d8) 
Mohammad Nabi, a poppy farmer in Nad Ali, said: “The Taliban will not be affected as much as ordinary people. Farmers are not growing poppies for fun. If factories are closed and businesses are gone, how will they provide food for their families?” 
(https://www.reuters.com/article/us-afghanistan-drugs/u-s-strikes-on-taliban-opium-labs-wont-work-say-afghan-farmers-idUSKBN1DN18Q)
Nicholson has said that the U.S. will “refrain from targeting the poppy crop, saying that the Taliban is often forcing farmers to grow the illicit crop” 
(http://edition.cnn.com/2017/11/20/politics/us-afghanistan-airstrikes-drug-processing/index.html) 
The Taliban can still make money from exporting the crop raw rather than as a refined product. Rouhani’s support for the campaign could lead to further backlash from government officials if the poppy fields are eventually targeted: Also worth a read: https://www.nytimes.com/2016/02/16/world/asia/afghanistan-opium-heroin-taliban-helmand.html

Well, at the risk of seeming morbid, this is a factor for actuarial life tables as much as for knowledge of the minutiae of Afghan politics.  I was attracted to this question because the crowd consensus (0% at the moment) implies that a 68-year-old Afghan will 100% likely still be alive in 7 months.  That is ... overconfident. Let's start with with the basics.  A 68yo male in a first world setting (and Ghani has been raised in a family situation that afforded him the opportunities of higher education, so that dataset is probably more relevant than the life expectancy of a 68yo Afghan goat herder) has a roughly 2% chance of dying in the next 12 months.  Ghani is known to have had a partial gastrectomy for cancer (http://edition.cnn.com/2014/12/08/world/ashraf-ghani-fast-facts/index.html), and is in what would be one of the most stressful and physiologically draining jobs in the world.  Those factors in themselves would probably double his risk of death = 4% in 12 months, call it  2% in the next 7 months. Then factor in the risk of violent death and "disappearance", or the risk of the Afghan regime collapsing ...  Those are not quantifiable for me, but would have to be more than 0%.  Especially so as the current power sharing arrangement (president vs CEO) seems to be unstable, and seems to put Abdullah in a prime position to push for sole presidency if Ghani shows any weakness, or becomes a liability in the eyes of the foreign sponsors of the Afghan government.  So, what, a 1 in 50 (2%) chance of something blowing up politically (or literally)? That gives a total 0.04 probability for the question.  In other words, 1:24 odds that Ghani will [cease to be]:[remain] president.  That seems about right as an initial punt.
Current situation doesn't seem bad enough to warrant his exit but if things escalate then he might make a hasty exit.
This is only because he might choke on something he's eating or have some other sort of accidental demise.

The LA times article from July states: “Ghani has repeatedly vowed to reform the security sector and promised an inquiry into the killings of protesters, although no tangible steps have been taken.” 
(http://beta.latimes.com/world/asia/la-fg-afghanistan-protest-20170703-story.html)
In terms of the security sector this is not necessarily the case. In a recent conversation at the Council on Foreign Relations, Ghani said: “The overarching framework is the four-year security reform program under which our security forces would be overhauled in terms of leadership and management and systems and processes. This process is fully underway in the Ministry of Defense”. (https://www.cfr.org/event/conversation-mohammad-ashraf-ghani)  According to the SIGAR report, 18.2% of districts are under government control, and 38.6% are under government influence. However, the majority 20.7 million (63.7%) still live in areas controlled or influenced by the government. 
Afghanistan is due to hold parliamentary and district elections on July 7th 2018. (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-afghanistan-election/afghanistan-to-hold-elections-in-july-next-year-idUSKBN19D258) Echoing the points that @acohen and @Raahul_Kumar are making: “The U.S. has a vital interest in preserving the many political, economic and security gains that have been achieved in Afghanistan since 2001” (https://www.cfr.org/interactives/global-conflict-tracker#!/conflict/taliban-in-afghanistan) 
And the U.S. is still supporting Ghani; the Special Inspector General for Afghanistan Reconstruction (SIGAR) “will keep abreast the implementation of the Kabul Compact, an Afghan-led initiative announced in August to “demonstrate the governments commitment to creating a peaceful, stable and prosperous society. The compact process consists of four U.S.- and Afghan-chaired working groups covering governance, economic development, peace and reconciliation, and security issues.” (https://www.sigar.mil/pdf/quarterlyreports/2017-10-30qr.pdf)  Though as @lsgold7 said, the IEC and EEC are “under increasing fire from a growing number of political groups and election observer bodies.” 
This is due to “allegations of financial corruption, government interference and divisions within the two commissions” 
Political groups called for the electoral commissioners to be sacked - Ghani has now sacked the chair of the IEC. (https://www.afghanistan-analysts.org/afghanistan-election-conundrum-1-political-pressure-on-commissioners-puts-2018-vote-in-doubt/) 
Seems unlikely that Ghani will be ousted by another politician in the next 8 months: Gulbuddin Hekmatyar, Afghan warlord, now leader of the Hezb-i Islami party, have faced some legal trouble (https://www.afghanistan-analysts.org/a-matter-of-registration-factional-tensions-in-hezb-e-islami/). 
Hekmatyar “received more U.S. assistance to fight the Soviet invasion than any other mujahideen. However he later “turned against Americans, supporting and orchestrating attacks on U.S. forces and civilians in Afghanistan” 
It seems unlikely that the current U.S. administration would favour Hekmatyar over Ghani, especially as he has “declared his party’s support for the current government, adding that there was no proper alternative” (https://www.afghanistan-analysts.org/a-matter-of-registration-factional-tensions-in-hezb-e-islami/) though he did meet with high ranking diplomats on return to Kabul https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/oct/24/kabul-welcomes-the-afghan-warlord-who-once-shelled-its-citizens  I expect the biggest indication of Ghani abandoning the role as president or being forced out, will come down to any possible corruption becoming public knowledge and the progress of the new U.S.-Afghan strategy.

Afghan Analysts Network analyzes how neither electoral commission is functioning 
Under these circumstances an election of any kind unlikely.

Unless I'm missing something Ghani doesn't seem to be unstable or in danger. Given the massive outside support I have trouble imagining how he gets overthrown. Seems to me that a question about the PM of Pakistan would be a much more interesting question.
